title: Lowdham Walks

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Farmland near Lowdham
images.caption: Farmland near Lowdham. The fields are being sown with winter cereal. The distant house is The Hut, a late 20th Century mansion in classical style.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Valley of the Cocker Beck
images.caption: Valley of the Cocker Beck

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Lambley Reed Pond
images.caption:
Lambley Reed Pond. The Conservation Area report of Gedling Borough Council comments:
"The reserve is an area of pasture with a large stream-fed pond in the middle. The pond was originally a medieval stew or fish pond that was later filled in, before being re-opened in 1974. The pond and pasture combine to make an attractive natural space adjacent to the village."
The pasture is used for cattle grazing and the reserve is managed by the Notts Wildlife Trust. Note the work being carried out to improve the drinking area for the cattle using the adjacent pasture.

images.title: Alan Murray-Rust / Field entrance
images.caption: Field entrance. The traditional gateway has been abandoned to allow free passage of modern arable machinery, although the stile and bridleway gate remain, unused.

images.title: Andy Jamieson / Track leading to Lowdham
images.caption: Track leading to Lowdham

description: This picturesque Nottinghamshire village is located in a pleasant rural spot in between Nottingham and Southwell . The historic village includes a railway station on the Nottingham to Lincoln Line, a Grade I listed church that dates back to the 13th century times and a few nice pubs to relax in after your exercise. This circular walk takes you west of the village to explore the attractive countryside in the valley of the Cocker Beck. The walk starts in the village and heads west, passing the old hall and the church. You continue west along a footpath before turning south to pick up a trail along the Cocker Beck. This will take you towards the neighbouring village of Lambley where you could pay a visit to the lovely Lambley Dumbles . This route heads north along Green Lane before turning east along a bridleway which runs past the Lowdham Grange prison. Shortly after you return to Lowdham.
